title: Seneca Falls Convention
people: Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Lucretia Mott, Frederick Douglass, Mary Ann M'Clintock
topic: suffrage, women's rights
description: The first women's rights convention was held over a two-day period in which women's rights were lectured upon and discussed[1].
citation: Dumenil, L. (2012). The Oxford Encyclopedia of American Social History: Men's-YMCA. Oxford University Press. It was somewhat inspired by World Anti-Slavery Convention's exclusion of women (1840), and the Anti-Slavery Convention of American Women (1837).
notes: Somewhat inspired by World Anti-Slavery Convention's (1840) exclusion of women, and the Anti-Slavery Convention of American Women (1837)

title: National Women's Rights Conventions
people: Lucy Stone, Paulina Wright Davis, Sarah H. Earle, William Lloyd Garrison, William Henry Channing, Wendell Phillips, Harriot Kezia Hunt, Ernestine Rose, Antoinette Brown, Sojourner Truth, Stephen Symonds Foster, Abby Kelley Foster, Abby H. Price, Lucretia Mott, Frederick Douglass
topic: suffrage, women's rights, equal wages, education, equal opportunities, property rights, marriage reform, temperance
description: During the first, more than 1,000 suffrage supporters met in Worcester, Massachusetts[1] to discuss various women's rights. These annual meetings continued 'til the Civil War in 1860 and only resumed in 1866 but quickly faded.
citation: First National Women's Rights Convention. (n.d.). [Web page]. Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.loc.gov/exhibitions/women-fight-for-the-vote/about-this-exhibition/seneca-falls-and-building-a-movement-1776-1890/seneca-falls-and-the-start-of-annual-conventions/first-national-womens-rights-convention/

title: The Provincial Freeman newspaper
people: Mary Ann Shadd, Samuel Ringgold Ward
topic: abolitionism, racism, discrimination, temperance
description: Mary Ann Shadd became one of the first female journalists in Canada, and the first Black woman to publish a newspaper in Canada and North America[1].
citation: Mary Ann Shadd | Biography & Facts | Britannica. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Mary-Ann-Shadd-Cary

title: American Equal Rights Association (AERA)
people: Harriet Purvis, Sarah Remond, Sojourner Truth, Abby Kelley Foster, Susan B. Anthony, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Lucy Stone
topic: suffrage, racism, discrimination, equal rights
description: Created at the 11th National Women's Rights Convention, the AERA worked for both black men's suffrage as well as all women's suffrage. It later split into the National Woman Suffrage Association (NWSA) and the American Woman Suffrage Association (AWSA) due to differing beliefs over methods by which to gain suffrage, including the order in which suffrage was to be gained.
citation: American Equal Rights Association Memorial | DocsTeach. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.docsteach.org/documents/document/aera-memorial

title: Working Women's Association (WWA)
topic: labor rights, equal rights, discrimination
description: Created in response to exclusion of women in workers unions (specifically in printing and sewing trades), it was the first feminist organization of women workers in the USA[1].
citation: Taylor, V. (1989). Sisterhood, Solidarity, and Modern Feminism. Gender and Society, 3(2), 277-286.

title: National Woman Suffrage Association (NWSA)
people: Susan B. Anthony, Elizabeth Cady Stanton
topic: suffrage, gender equality, marriage reform
description: Resulted from a divide over 15th Amendment and its allowance of black men and black men only being added allowance to vote[1]. It later merged with American Woman Suffrage Association (AWSA) to form National American Woman Suffrage Association (NAWSA).
citation: National Woman Suffrage Association | Significance & Facts | Britannica. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.britannica.com/topic/National-Woman-Suffrage-Association

title: American Woman Suffrage Association (AWSA)
people: Lucy Stone, Henry B. Blackwell, Julia Ward Howe, T.W. Higginson
topic: suffrage, abolitionism
description: Resulted from a divide over 15th Amendment and its allowance of black men and black men only being added allowance to vote. It later merged with National Woman Suffrage Association (NWSA) to form National American Woman Suffrage Association (NAWSA).
citation: American Woman Suffrage Association | American Organization | Britannica. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.britannica.com/topic/National-Woman-Suffrage-Association

title: Woman's Christian Temperance Union (WCTU)
people: Annie Wittenmyer, Frances Willard
topic: suffrage, temperance, women's protection, children's protection, age of consent, violence, health, poverty
description: A worldwide organization founded in the USA, it aims to educate on the dangers of substance abuse[1]. While not directly focused on suffrage, it has supported and worked towards this and other women's rights.
citation: History of the WCTU. (n.d.). WCTU. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.wctu.org/history

title: Amendment for Women's Suffrage
topic: suffrage, equal rights, women's rights, discrimination, racism
description: While first introduced to Congress in 1878, it did not pass the House of Representatives until 1919, and was certified as ratified in 1920. It did allow American women to vote, but non-white women were not necessarily included as state voting laws still presented obstacles [1].
citation: 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution: Women's Right to Vote (1920). (2021, September 21). National Archives. https://www.archives.gov/milestone-documents/19th-amendment
notes: Introduced in 1878, certified in 1920 as the 19th Amendment

title: WCTU New Zealand (WCTU NZ)
people: Mary Clement Leavitt
topic: suffrage, temperance, women's protection, children's protection, age of consent
description: It "worked to promote temperance, Christian values, and social reform, and to abolish the trade in alcohol and drugs" while also supporting women's suffrage movements worldwide as it was believed this could also help protect women[1].

title: Contagious Diseases Act Repealed
people: Josephine Butler
topic: equal rights, discrimination, women's rights, women's protection
description: This Act enforced compulsory examination of women and allowed them to be locked away if they were found to have veneral diseases. Men were not examined[1].
citation: The Contagious Diseases Act. (n.d.). Policy Navigator. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://navigator.health.org.uk/theme/contagious-diseases-act

title: Women's Suffrage League
people: Rose Scott, Edward Charles Stirling, Mary Lee, Hector McLennan, Rose Birks, Mary Colton, Catherine Helen Spence
topic: suffrage, temperance, women's rights, women's protection, children's protection, age of consent, education
description: Its creation ratified at a WCTU meeting, the Women's Suffrage League campaigned for better rights for women. It focused primarily on all women's suffrage - some were already enfranchised under the Municipal Corporations Act of 1861 - but also on education, women's protection, and other such topics.
citation: Australia, S. L. of S. (n.d.). LibGuides: South Australian Women: Women's suffrage. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://guides.slsa.sa.gov.au/SAwomen/womens_suffrage

title: National American Woman Suffrage Association (NAWSA)
people: Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Lucy Stone, Susan B. Anthony
topic: suffrage, women's rights
description: Created by merging (or reuniting) the National Woman Suffrage Association and the American Woman Suffrage Association, after 21 years of separate operation[1]. It played a major role in passing the 19th Amendment.
citation: National American Woman Suffrage Association | American organization | Britannica. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.britannica.com/topic/National-American-Woman-Suffrage-Association

title: Electoral Bill Containing Women's Suffrage Passed
people: Kate Sheppard
topic: suffrage
description: The first self-governing country in the world in which all adult women in New Zealand (with some exceptions, notably aliens and inmates of prisons and asylums) had the right to vote in parliamentary elections. Kate Sheppard's petitions aided this work greatly, amassing nearly 32,000 signatures.
citation: New Zealand women and the vote. (n.d.). Retrieved October 26, 2021. https://nzhistory.govt.nz/politics/womens-suffrage
notes: Nearly 32,000 signatures on petition from 1893. Suffragettes gave their supporters in Parliament white camellias to wear in their buttonholes.

title: South Australian Suffrage for State Elections
people: Mary Lee, Catherine Helen Spence, Elizabeth Webb Nicholls
topic: suffrage, discrimination, racism
description: A Constitutional Amendment, meaning it was endorsed by the Queen, which allowed women to vote for the first time in South Australian state elections[1]. However, this excluded men and women who were aboriginal natives of Australia, Africa, Asia, or the Pacific Islands (bar New Zealand), unless entitled under section 41 of the constitution [2].
citation: The South Australian women's suffrage campaign (South Australia). (n.d.). [Collection]. Retrieved April 4, 2022, from https://officeforwomen.sa.gov.au/womens-policy/125th-anniversary-of-suffrage/the-south-australian-womens-suffrage-campaign -- Documenting Democracy. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022, from https://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/scan-sid-164.html
notes: ...accidentally also gave women the right to hold legislative office...Section 41 of Australian Constitution

title: The National Association of Colored Women (NACW)
people: Mary Church Terrell
topic: suffrage, racism, discrimination
description: Known today as the National Association of Colored Women's Clubs (NACWC), this association formed in response to the exclusion of issues regarding race in other women's rights associations of the day, as well as their recorded histories. Women of color were even excluded from meetings held by the most powerful suffrage organizations, like the NAWSA.
citation: Lange, A. (n.d.). National Association of Colored Women. History of U.S. Woman's Suffrage. Retrieved April 4, 2022. http://www.crusadeforthevote.org/nacw
notes: Made up of clubs / "also led efforts to improve education, and care for both children and the elderly

title: Fédération nationale Saint-Jean-Baptiste (FNSJB)
people: Joséphine Marchand-Dandurand, Caroline Dessaulles-Béique, Marie Lacoste-Gérin-Lajoie, Marguerite Thibaudeau
topic: suffrage, equal rights, women's protection, children's protection
description: Sought to gain equal rights and suffrage, but also to increase protections for mothers and their families. It initiated major reforms in the political, economic, and social realms of Canada.
citation: Cohen, Y. (2017, November 8). Fédération nationale Saint-Jean-Baptiste | The Canadian Encyclopedia. The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/federation-nationale-saint-jean-baptiste
notes: ...organized French- and English-speaking women often operated in what has been called “two solitudes” (that is, separate from one another and largely non-communicative)

title: Woman Suffrage Procession
people: Alice Paul, Lucy Burns, Inez Milholland, Ida B. Wells-Barnett, Marie Louise Bottineau Baldwin
topic: suffrage, racism, discrimination
description: First suffragist parade took place the day before Woodrow Wilson's inaugeration wherein thousands of women marched along the same route on Pennsylvania Avenue that he would take. The pathway was blocked temporarily by crowds, but there was also discrimination towards women of color even before the parade started in that some black women were asked to stand further back or even not attend.
citation: 1913 Woman Suffrage Procession (U.S. National Park Service). (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.nps.gov/articles/woman-suffrage-procession1913.htm

title: National Woman's Party (NWP)
people: Alice Paul, Lucy Burns
topic: suffrage, equal rights, women's rights
description: Briefly known as the Woman's Party of Western Voters, this Party came from Congressional Union for Woman Suffrage (initiated to assist the NAWSA Congressional Committee). It made use of the more militant methods from British suffragette movement[1].
citation: Historical Overview of the National Womans Party | Library of Congress . (n.d.). [Web page]. Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. 20540 USA. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.loc.gov/collections/women-of-protest/articles-and-essays/historical-overview-of-the-national-womans-party/

title: First woman elected to the House of Representatives
people: Jeannette Rankin
topic: suffrage
description: Jeannette Rankin of Montana was the first woman to hold federal office in the USA, and is still the only woman from Montana elected (as of 2022).
citation: Jeannette Rankin | American politician | Britannica. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jeannette-Rankin

title: First International Women's Day
topic: suffrage, public affairs, political participation, discrimination
description: More than one million people attended IWD rallies to support increased women's rights on March 19, 1911[1], but it is now celebrated on March 8th after Russia's unofficial-to-offical adoption of it from 1917 to 1922[2].
citation: History of International Women's Day. (2020, November 19). International Women's Day. https://www.internationalwomensday.com/Activity/15586/The-history-of-IWD -- Smith, A. (2018, March 6). A History of International Women's Day. History Hub. http://historyhub.ie/a-history-of-international-womens-day

title: Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (WILPF)
people: Agnes MacPhail
topic: equal rights, peace, public affairs, women's rights
description: Established with the aim to develop mediation strategies to end World War I and then eradicate the root causes of war[1]. They continue to seek to bridge gaps, reach equality, share knowledge, and stand against violence[2].
citation: Herstory. (n.d.). WILPF. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.wilpf.org/our-herstory/ -- Vision. (n.d.). WILPF. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.wilpf.org/vision/

title: Female enfranchisement in Canada
topic: suffrage, racism, discrimination
description: Female citizens aged 21 or over were allowed to vote in federal elections regardless of whether they had obtained provincial franchise[1]. Black Canadians had to fight for slavery abolition under British rule (they were deemed property, not persons), Indigenous people only recieved full voting rights progressively from 1949/1969, and Asian Canadians weren't allowed to vote until after World War II.
citation: Strong-Boag, V. (2016, June 21). Women's Suffrage in Canada | The Canadian Encyclopedia. The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/suffrage

title: League of Women Voters
topic: suffrage, education
description: Formed by the suffragists of the NAWSA, the League was designed to help women carry out their new responsibilities as voters once the 19th Amendment was fully ratified.
citation: History | League of Women Voters. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.lwv.org/about-us/history

title: Persons Case
people: Emily Murphy, Nellie McClung, Irene Parlby, Louise McKinney, Henrietta Muir Edwards
topic: political participation, public affairs, equal rights
description: In 1928, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled that women were not persons according to the the British North America Act (or Constitution Act, 1867). The Persons Case lead the way to establishing the right of women to be on the Senate and the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council reversed the Court's decision in 1929.
citation: Marshall, T., & Cruickshank, D. A. (2006, February 7). Persons Case | The Canadian Encyclopedia. The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/persons-case

title: Aba Women's Rebellion
people: Nwanyereuwa, Ikonnia, Mwannedia, Nwugo
topic: political participation, public affairs, direct taxation
description: Generally seen as the first large protest against British authority in West Africa, these protests were organized by rural women against the British-appointed Warrant Chiefs in order to demand back the rights taken from them under colonial rule.
citation: The Aba Women's War. (n.d.). Retrieved April 4, 2022. http://deappel.nl/en/files/the-aba-womens-war/

title: Charter of United Nations signed
topic: equal rights, labor rights, discrimination, women's rights, public affairs, peace, social justice, racism
description: The Charter of the United Nations is the founding document of the United Nations and went into force on 1945/10/24. It stated that the United Nations have a determination "to reaffirm faith in...the equal rights of men and women"[2].
citation: Charter of the United Nations, done at San Francisco June 26, 1945. (n.d.). United States Department of State. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.state.gov/charter-of-the-united-nations-san-francisco-june-26-1945/ -- Francisco, S. (n.d.). STATUTE OF THE INTERNATIONAL COURT OF JUSTICE. 54.

title: Dublin Laundry Strike
topic: labor rights
description: Women working with laundry in Dublin went on strike for 14 weeks against the working conditions, low wages, overtime, and limited leave. They won all Irish workers a second week's annual holidays from the following year onwards[1].
citation: The 1945 Laundry Strike – Irish Women Workers Union. (n.d.). Retrieved October 26, 2021. https://womenworkersunion.ie/history/the-1945-laundry-strike/

title: Universal Declaration of Human Rights
topic: equal rights, discrimination
description: A major milestone which sets out fundamental human rights. It is widely recognized as having inspired, and paved the way for, the adoption of more than seventy human rights treaties, applied today on a permanent basis at global and regional levels[1].
citation: Universal Declaration of Human Rights. (n.d.). United Nations; United Nations. Retrieved October 26, 2021. https://www.un.org/en/about-us/universal-declaration-of-human-rights

title: Canadian Voice of Women for Peace (VOW)
people: Thérèse Casgrain, Grace Hartman, Ursula Franklin
topic: peace, social justice, education, disarmament
description: An organization focusing on education, advocacy and women's rights. It opposes violence and war and promotes nuclear disarmament, peace and social justice [1].
citation: Macpherson, K., & Marshall, T. (2006, February 7). Canadian Voice of Women for Peace | The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/voice-of-women

title: Canadian Bill of Rights
topic: equal rights, suffrage, discrimination, gender equality, racism
description: It was the earliest expression of human rights law at the federal level in Canada, but was somewhat ineffective as it applied only to federal statues and not provincial ones. It is still technically in effect, but the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms superceded it in 1982.
citation: McConnell, W. H. (2006, February 7). Canadian Bill of Rights | The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/canadian-bill-of-rights

title: Fédération des femmes du Québec
people: Thérèse Casgrain, Réjane Laberge-Colas, Monique Bégin
topic: equal rights, violence, discrimination, protection for women
description: Created to defend the interests and rights of women without distinction of race, ethnic origin, color or creed, women and associations to coordinate their activities in the field of social action.
citation: Histoire. (n.d.). Fédération des femmes du Québec. Retrieved April 4, 2022. https://www.ffq.qc.ca/fr/notre-histoire-ffq

title: Royal Commission on the Status of Women in Canada
people: Lester B. Pearson, Laura Sabia, Florence Bird, Elsie MacGill, Lola M. Lange, Jeanne Lapointe, Doris Ogilvie, Jacques Henripin, John Peters Humphrey
topic: equal rights, equal pay, maternity leave, child care, birth control, reproductive rights, family law reform, education, labor rights, alimony, racism, discrimination
description: The commission inquired into and reported on the status of women in Canada, and made specific recommendations to the federal government to ensure equality for women in all aspects of society. This was also the first time a Royal Commission of inquiry had been chaired by a woman, Florence Bird[1].
citation: Morris, C. (2006, February 7). Royal Commission on the Status of Women in Canada | The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/royal-commission-on-the-status-of-women-in-canada

title: Vancouver Women's Caucus (VWC)
topic: birth control, equal rights, education, reproductive rights
description: Feminist organization who were responsible for effectively shutting down Parliament for the first time in Canadian history with their Abortion Caravan (a cross country protest opposing the 1969 amendments to the Criminal Code).
citation: Sethna, C., & Hewitt, S. (2009). Clandestine Operations: The Vancouver Women's Caucus, the Abortion Caravan, and the RCMP. The Canadian Historical Review, 90(3), 463–495. https://doi.org/10.1353/can.0.0189

title: Front de libération des femmes du Québec (FLF)
people: Lise Landry, Suzanne Plamondon
topic: birth control, equal pay, housework enumeration, objectification, family unit redefinition, equal rights, abortion, discrimination
description: Despite its short time active, this organization's work was part of removing Quebec's exclusion of women serving as jurors, as well as increasing daycare centers and abortion services. It would also provide support to women workers on picket lines.
citation: Maillé, C. (2021, February 22). Front de libération des femmes du Québec | The Canadian Encyclopedia. The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/front-de-liberation-des-femmes-du-quebec

title: National Action Committee on the Status of Women (NAC)
people: Laura Sabia, Doris Anderson
topic: poverty, racism, sexuality, gender equality, equal rights, violence, birth control, women's rights, education, public affairs, labor rights
description: Founded as a pressure group to lobby for the implementation of the 167 recommendations made in the Royal Commission on the Status of Women in Canada's 1970 report.
citation: Anderson, D., & Lambert, M.-E. (2006, February 7). National Action Committee on the Status of Women | The Canadian Encyclopedia. The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/national-action-committee-on-the-status-of-women
notes: Dissolved due to funding problems, "A coalition of 22 groups when it originated under the name of the National Ad Hoc Committee on the Status of Women, the National Action Committee eventually grew into the largest national feminist organization with a total of 700 groups claiming affiliation

title: Canadian Abortion Rights Action League (CARAL)
people: June Callwood, Kay Macpherson, Lorna Grant, Eleanor Wright Pelrine, Esther Greenglass, Henry Morgentaler, Norma Scarborough
topic: abortion, contraception, birth control, women's rights, reproductive rights
description: Originally titled the Canadian Association for the Repeal of the Abortion Laws, this organization worked towards more accessible birth control and legal abortions. Later, a separate but related organization Childbirth by Choice was created to deal with education and research.
citation: Canadian Abortion Rights Action League (CARAL) / L'Association canadienne pour le droits à l'avortement (ACDA) – Rise Up! Feminist Digital Archive. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://riseupfeministarchive.ca/activism/organizations/canadian-abortion-rights-action-league-association-caral/
notes: Was first Canadian Association for Repeal of the Abortion Law (CARAL), was replaced with Abortion Rights Coalition of Canada in 2005

title: Native Women's Association of Canada (NWAC)
people: Bertha Clark-Jones
topic: equal rights, discrimination, labor rights, violence, women's rights, cultural preservation, gender equality, racism, health, social justice, environmental issues
description: This organization aims to \"promote equality for Indigenous women, girls, Two-spirit and gender diverse people, including LGBTQ+ people\" on both a national and international level.[1]
citation: About Native Women's Association of Canada. (n.d.). Native Women's Association of Canada. Retrieved April 5, 2022 https://www.nwac.ca/about/

title: Icelandic Women's Day Off
topic: labor rights, discrimination
description: Protesting wage discrepancy and unfair employment practices, women left their homes and workplaces to demonstrate their importance in the Icelandic society. The first Gender Equality Act which banned discrimination based on gender, was adopted in 1976 as a response to this event.[1]
citation: Hofverberg, E. (2022, March 8). Kvennafridagurinn – The Day Icelandic Women Went on Strike | In Custodia Legis: Law Librarians of Congress [Webpage]. https://blogs.loc.gov/law/2022/03/kvennafridagurinn-the-day-icelandic-women-went-on-strike/

title: Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) signed
people: Hilary Gbedemah
topic: discrimination, violence, gender equality, public affairs, sexuality
description: An international treaty or bill of rights, similar to International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (ICERD). It is said to be \"the culmination of more than thirty years of work by the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women.\"[1]
citation: Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women New York, 18 December 1979. (n.d.). OHCHR. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://www.ohchr.org/en/instruments-mechanisms/instruments/convention-elimination-all-forms-discrimination-against-women

title: Canada's first female Speaker of the House of Commons
people: Jeanne Sauvé
topic: public affairs, equal rights, women's rights
description: She was elected to the House of Commons in 1972, serving as minister of the Crown until 1980 when she became a speaker. She then went on to become the first female Governer General of Canada in 1984.
citation: Tremblay, J. (2008, January 15). Jeanne Sauvé | The Canadian Encyclopedia. The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/jeanne-mathilde-sauve
notes: Include explanation of what a governer general does

title: Canadian Association for the Advancement of Women in Sport (CAAWS)
people: Betty Baxter, Micheline LeGuillou, Tom Bedecki, Pam Lewis, Wendy Bedingfield, Mary Lyons, Carole Bishop, Shirley Mardsen, Lyse Blanchard, Suzanne Mason, Peggy Brown, Rose Mercier, Elizabeth Chard, Diane Palmason, Monique Charlebois, Anne Popma, Patricia Cormie, Joan Rapsavage, Muriel Duckworth, Jane Rattray, Laurel Goodacre, Dorothy Richardson, Ann Hall, Sandy Straw, Cheryl Hassen, Nancy Theberge, Jo Hauser, Susan Vail, Abby Hoffman, Penny Werthner, Mary Keyes, Nancy Wood, Kathy Lane, Pat Lawson, Marion Lay, Sandra Kirby
topic: equal rights, discrimination
description: Its objective was \"to see the enhanced presence of girls and women at all levels and in all areas\"[1] and it continues to work for this even now.
citation: Our Story. (n.d.). Canadian Women & Sport. Retrieved October 28, 2021. https://womenandsport.ca/about/our-story/

title: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
people: Pierre Trudeau, Barry Strayer
topic: democratic rights, labor rights, equal rights, gender equality, language rights, discrimination, racism, cultural preservation, public affairs
description: Any person in Canada has the rights and freedoms stated within the Charter, bar some exceptions like voting being reserved for citizens. It has undergone some revisions, increasing clarity of of sections and, for example, stating that anglophone and francophone communities have equal rights.
citation: Heritage, C. (2017, October 23). Guide to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. https://www.canada.ca/en/canadian-heritage/services/how-rights-protected/guide-canadian-charter-rights-freedoms.html

title: Pauktuutit
topic: equal rights, discrimination, public affairs, violence, gender equality, women's protection, children's protection, cultural preservation, health
description: This organization's purpose is \"to foster a greater awareness of the needs of Inuit women, and to encourage their participation in community, regional and national concerns in relation to social, cultural and economic development\."[1]
citation: About Us. (n.d.). Pauktuutit Inuit Women of Canada. Retrieved April 5, 2022, from https://q0599p9vrr.wpdns.site/about-us/

title: Canada's first female governor general
people: Jeanne Sauvé
topic: public affairs, equal rights, women's rights
description: After becoming Canada's first woman to be Speaker of the House of Commons in 1980, she went on to reach this accomplishment as well, naming it "a magnificent breakthrough for women."[1]
citation: Tremblay, J. (2008, January 15). Jeanne Sauvé | The Canadian Encyclopedia. The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/jeanne-mathilde-sauve

title: Women's Legal Education and Action Fund (LEAF)
people: Nancy Ruth
topic: public affairs, discrimination, gender equality, sexuality, ableism, racism, birth control
description: Seeking to level out gender inequality, this group focuses on \"challenging laws, policies, and practices that discriminate against equality guarantees enshrined in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, most notably sections 15 and 28\".[1]
citation: Our Story. (n.d.). LEAF. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://www.leaf.ca/our-story/

title: DisAbled Women's Network Canada (DAWN)
topic: poverty, exclusion, discrimination, violence, equal rights, public affairs, gender equality, ableism, racism
description: Aiming to \"end the poverty, isolation, discrimination and violence experienced by women with disabilities and Deaf women,\"[1] this group aims to address issues and also offer resources to support those struggling within them.
citation: DAWN-RAFH :: Our Mission and Vision. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://www.dawncanada.net/about/our-mission-and-vision/

title: National Organization of Immigrant and Visible Minority Women of Canada (NOIVMWC)
topic: gender equality, equal rights, discrimination, racism
description: Made to "ensure equality for immigrant and visible minority women within a bilingual Canada"[1] by liasing with other women's groups, enacting strategies to reduce social issues, acting as advocates and raising awareness on issues involving immigrant and visible minority women.
citation: National Organization of Immigrant and Visible Minority Women (NOIVMWC) – Rise Up! Feminist Digital Archive. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://riseupfeministarchive.ca/activism/organizations/national-organization-of-immigrant-and-visible-minority-women-noivmwc/

title: Raging Grannies
country: CA, USA, AU, IE, IL, NZ, EN, SCT
topic: social justice, peace, discrimination, ageism, equal rights, environmentalism, violence, racism
description: First called the Nuclear Emergency Response Team (NERT), and initially formed as a reaction to the threat to health and environment posed by the US Navy vessels surrounding Victoria, this group has since developed to focus on social and political issues on both a national and international level. Despite indications of their name, they focus on keeping protests peaceful and often use satire in various forms instead.
citation: Herstory – Raging Grannies International. (n.d.). Retrieved November 10, 2021. https://raginggrannies.org/herstory/

title: Inaugeration of White Ribbon Day
topic: violence, women's rights, discrimination, equal rights, protection of women and children
description: Officially named the National Day of Remembrance and Action on Violence Against Women, this commemorates the anniversary of the Montreal Massacre. It is observed during the 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence, an international campaign which begins with the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women on November 25th and ending with World Human Rights Day on December 10th.
citation: NATIONAL DAY OF REMEMBRANCE AND ACTION ON VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN - December 6. (n.d.). National Day Calendar. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://nationaldaycalendar.com/national-day-of-remembrance-and-action-on-violence-against-women-december-6/

title: Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women (DEVAW)
topic: equal rights, discrimination, violence
description: Adopted without vote[1], this Declaration echoes the values in the Universal Declaration of Human rights but focuses specifically on combating violence against women. The first and second Articles contain well-known definitions of what violence against women means.[2]
citation: Resolutions adopted by the General Assembly at its 48th session: (2014, January 16). https://web.archive.org/web/20140116222203/http://www.un.org/depts/dhl/resguide/r48_en.shtml -- A/RES/48/104—Declaration on the Elimination of Violence against Women—UN Documents: Gathering a body of global agreements. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. http://www.un-documents.net/a48r104.htm

title: First Women's Memorial March
people: Linda Ann Joe, Cheryl Ann Joe
topic: violence, discrimination, women's rights, equal rights, protection of women and children, racism, class disparity
description: An annually held event which honors the Indigenous woman Cheryl Ann Joe, and all other missing and/or murdered Indigenous women and girls. More than 970 names have been added to the list of women since the first March[1].
citation: <em>Conn, H. (2020, January 22). Women's Memorial March | The Canadian Encyclopedia<em>. The Canadian Encyclopedia. https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/women-s-memorial-march

title: Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993
topic: equal rights, labor rights, discrimination, women's protection, children's protection, women's rights
description: Requires employers to provide employees with job-protected and unpaid leave for qualified medical and family reasons.
citation: The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 | U.S. Department of Labor. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/laws-and-regulations/laws/fmla

title: Violence Against Women Act of 1994 (VAWA)
people: Jack Brooks
topic: violence, protection of women and children, public affairs, equal rights, women's rights
description: Helped expand the available tools to combat violence against women and also protect women from it in the future. It also mandates funding for studies of violence against women specifically. The Act has been expanded several times, including civil rights remedies for victims of gender-motivated crimes, the inclusion of American Indians, same-sex couples, and victims of sex-trafficking.
citation: Violence Against Women Act | Definition & History | Britannica. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://www.britannica.com/event/Violence-Against-Women-Act

title: First female Prime Minister of New Zealand
people: Jenny Shipley
topic: political participation, public affairs
description: Also the first female leader of the National Party, Shipley came to power after staging a coup against previous Prime Minister Jim Bolger. She has since received the Dame Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit, and now chairs Global Women NZ and takes part in a number of other social efforts.
citation: McLean, G. (Updated 2020, November 12). Jenny Shipley | NZHistory, New Zealand history online. https://nzhistory.govt.nz/people/jenny-shipley

title: First V-Day
people: Eve Ensler
topic: violence, discrimination, women's rights, equal rights, women's protection, children's protection, equal rights, human trafficking
description: Founded by V (formerly Eve Ensler), the author of the Vagina Monologues it is \"a global activist movement to end violence against all women and girls\" and has raised over $120 million in support various groups and organizations also working for the same purpose.[1]
citation: ABOUT V-DAY. (n.d.). V-Day. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://www.vday.org/about-v-day/

title: United Nations Security Council Resolution 1325
topic: violence, women's rights
description: The first landmark Security Council resolution on women, peace and security, and addresses the impact of war on women and the importance of women's full and equal participation. It also calls for special measures to protect women and girls from conflict-related sexual violence and outlines gender-related responsibilities of the United Nations in different political and programmatic areas.[1]
citation: S/RES/1325. Security Council Resolution on women and peace and security | UN Peacemaker. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://peacemaker.un.org/node/105

title: Equal Voice
people: Rosemary Speirs, Donna Dasko, Libby Burnham, Christina McCall
topic: public affairs, political participation, equal rights, women's rights, labor rights
description: This group is a national, bilingual, member-based, multipartisinal organization which advocates for and supports women and gender diverse candidates at all levels of government, from all political parties and all parts of the country.
citation: About. (n.d.). Equal Voice. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://equalvoice.ca/about/

title: Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace
people: Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, Leymah Gbowee, Crystal Roh Gawding, Comfort Freeman, Asatu Bah Kenneth
topic: peace, violence, women's rights
description: Women in Liberia staged a non-violent sit-in protest at the Executive Mansion leading to the end of a 14-year civil war. This lead to women being able to be in positions of political power, most notably Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf who made Liberia the first nation in Africa to elect a female head-of-state.
citation: The Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace Protests in Liberia – Participedia. (n.d.). Participedia. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://participedia.net/case/6791

title: March for Women's Lives (2004)
topic: reproductive rights, abortion, education, sexual health, women's rights, birth control, protection of women and children, discrimination
description: On the day, 1.15 million people marched to support abortion rights, birth control, reproductive healthcare options, sex education, to show support for mothers and children.
citation: Flashback: Over One Million March for Women's Lives | National Organization for Women. (2014, April 25). https://now.org/blog/over-one-million-march-for-womens-lives/

title: Abortion Rights Coalition of Canada (ARCC)
topic: reproductive rights, abortion, women's rights, birth control, self-identified
description: This group's mission is \"to ensure reproductive freedom by protecting and advancing rights and access to abortion and to quality reproductive health care\" and self-identifies as a group of national, pro-choice feminists.
citation: About Us. (n.d.). Abortion Rights Coalition of Canada. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://www.arcc-cdac.ca/about-us/

title: Equality Act 2006
topic: discrimination, gender equality, equal rights, women's rights, ageism, ableism, racism, sexuality
description: A precursor to the Equality Act of 2010, this Act created the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC), outlawed discrimination on the grounds of religion and belief, and allowed the government to introduce regulations outlawing discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation.
citation: Participation, E. (n.d.). Equality Act 2006 [Text]. Legislation.Gov.Uk; Statute Law Database. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2006/3/contents

title: Gulabi Gang
people: Sampat Pal Devi
topic: violence, women's rights
description: They are a vigilante group and their vision is to \"protect the powerless from abuse and fight corruption to ensure basic rights of the poor in rural areas and discourage traditions like child-marriages.\" The gang fights for women regardless of their caste and many members are part of lower castes.
citation: Gulabi Gang: Vision. (n.d.). Gulabi Gang. Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://gulabigang.in/vision.php

title: Voices-Voix
topic: gender equality, human rights, women's rights, immigrant and refugee settlement rights, Indigenous rights, racism, discrimination, public affairs, environmentalism, free speech, transparency
description: N/A: Requires more research but holds potential
citation: N/A -- Needs citations

title: First SlutWalk
topic: violence, discrimination, gender equality, human rights, women's rights, free speech, victim blaming, language reclaiming
description: This movement was a reaction to situations in which a victim of sexual assault was held at fault for the actions of the perpetrator, an action known as \"slut-shaming.\" Those in the movement seek to raise awareness and bring an end to this type of action, deeming it a part of what is known as \"rape culture.\" While it was first held in Canada, it has spread worldwide.
citation: SlutWalk Vancouver: A march to end rape culture. (2013, May 29). WAVAW Rape Crisis Centre. https://www.wavaw.ca/slutwalk-vancouver-a-march-to-end-rape-culture/ -- Needs better citation(s)

title: Idle No More
people: Nina Wilson, Sheelah Mclean, Sylvia McAdam Saysewahum, Jessica Gordon
topic: environmentalism, equal rights, human rights, Indigenous rights, discrimination, public affairs
description: Starting in November 2011, this group generally opposes certain types of resource exploitation, particularly on First Nations territory. It protests the Canadian government's dismantling of environmental protection laws, connects remote reserves to others, and works to protect the environment and the Indigenous people who live within it.
citation: About the Movement – idlenomore.ca. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://idlenomore.ca/about-the-movement/

title: Tunisia 2014 Constitution (Article 21)
topic: equal rights, discrimination
description: This Article states the \"the equality of rights and duties between all citizens, male and female, and equality between all regions\" thereby affirming such a concept on a Constitutional level.
citation: Constitution of the Republic of Tunisia 2014. (n.d.). Retrieved April 5, 2022. https://constitutions.unwomen.org/en/countries/africa/tunisia

title: A White Dress Doesn't Cover the Rape
topic: equal rights, women's rights, discrimination, violence, women's protection
description: A campaign against the Lebanese rape-marriage law Article 522 which succeeded with having the law abolished. The law had allowed men who had been convicted of sexual assault, abduction, or statutory rape against a woman to avoid the penalties if a marriage contract could be provided.
citation: <em>A White Dress Doesn't Cover the Rape Campaign by ABAAD wins the UN SDG Award! - Network of networks—Euro-Mediterranean Women's Foundation<em>. (2019, June 18). Euromedwomen.Foundation. https://www.euromedwomen.foundation/pg/en/news/view/8777/a-white-dress-doesnt-cover-rape-campaign-by-abaad-wins-un-sdg-award

title: Sulaliyyate women in Morocco gain equal land rights
topic: equal rights, land rights, women's rights
description: Since women couldn't own land, by tribal law, this put certain women (single, windowed, divorced, without sons) at a disadvantage. Men and women were then granted equal rights to benefit from incomes and profits gained from their land, and equal shares of land were then distributed in a lottery as a result of 10 years of advocacy efforts.
citation: Land rights at last for Sulaliyyate women in Morocco. (2018, August 29). UN Women. https://www.unwomen.org/news/stories/2018/8/feature-land-rights-at-last-for-sulaliyyate-women-in-morocco
